required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Clopidogrel and Ticagrelor on Microvascular Dysfunction in Acute Coronary Syndrome Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Clopidogrel and Ticagrelor on Microvascular Dysfunction in Acute Coronary Syndrome Patients: The Index of MIcrocirculatory Resistance After PCI in ACS Patients Study (TIMER Study)

brief_summary.textblock:
Ticagrelor is a non-thienophyridine, direct P2Y12 blocker that is more potent than clopidogrel and is associated with less interindividual variability. In the PLATO trial, it was found to be superior to clopidogrel with respect to cardiovascular outcomes and total mortality without increasing the risk of bleedings.
More potent and reversible receptor bindings are possible explanation for the superior outcomes. Beside the potent effect on inhibition of antiplatelet function, ticagrelor has previously been demonstrated to increase adenosine levels by inhibiting adenosine re-uptake in tissue level and can induce adenosine triphosphate (ATP) release from human red cells, which both stimulate vasodilation of in red blood cells.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Index of microcirculatory resistance (IMR) measured after successful coronary intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: IMR will be immediately assessed after successful PCI patients within 48hr from admission

secondary_outcome.measure: wall motion score index on three month later TTE from index PCI
secondary_outcome.time_frame: TTE will be assessed in all enrolled patients 3 month later from index PCI

criteria.textblock:
- Inclusion Criteria:
- Males and Females
- between the ages of 18 and 75 years
- STEMI patients treated with percutaneous coronary intervention
- Able to provide informed consent
- Exclusion Criteria:
- History of stroke or transient ischemic attack
- Platelet count < 100 000/Î¼L
- Known Bleeding Diathesis
- Hematocrit <30% or >52%
- Severe Liver Dysfunction
- Renal Insufficiency (Creatinine Clearance < 30ml/min)
- Pregnant females
- Cardiogenic shock or symptomatic hypotension or sitting SBP < 95 mmHg
